VERY_SHORT.string: When a Guru Becomes Imperfect: Spiritual Warning Signs

SHORT.string: The video discusses how to recognize when a guru is no longer a true spiritual guide. Warning signs include the guru demanding your presence at their ashram, using you for personal tasks, or insisting you must attend their gatherings. When a guru starts focusing on crowd numbers or political rallies, they have lost their spiritual purpose. The speaker advises that if your inner self does not bear witness to the guru's actions, you should stop following them. It's not necessary to blame yourself; sometimes it's better to preserve pure feelings for the guru from a distance rather than face potential disappointment up close.

MEDIUM.markdown_string:
### When a Guru Becomes Imperfect: Spiritual Warning Signs

In the journey of spiritual seeking, the relationship between a disciple and their guru is often considered sacred‚Äîa bond built on trust, guidance, and the shared aspiration for enlightenment. But what happens when that bond begins to fray? When the guru, once a beacon of light, starts showing signs of imperfection or even exploitation?

A poignant question was recently raised: ‚ÄúMy guru has grown old, and he calls me to his ashram, but I am unable to go. What should I do?‚Äù

The response offered was both direct and deeply insightful‚Äîa set of spiritual warning signs that every sincere seeker should recognize.

---

#### üö© The Guru Starts ‚ÄúCalling Out‚Äù to You

When a guru begins to *insist* that you come‚Äîsummoning you repeatedly, almost demanding your presence‚Äîit may be time to pause and reflect. As the speaker noted:

> ‚ÄúWhen the guru starts calling out to you insistently, that is the time to walk away.‚Äù

A true guide leads through silence, wisdom, and presence‚Äînot through pressure or emotional appeals. If you feel you are being ‚Äúcalled‚Äù in a way that feels more like a summons than an invitation, the guru may no longer be acting as a spiritual guide, but as a figure seeking validation or control.

---

#### üö© When the Guru Uses You for Personal Tasks

Another clear red flag emerges when the guru begins to use disciples to fulfill personal or organizational agendas:

> ‚ÄúWhen the guru starts getting their personal work done through you, or makes you feel that you *must* attend their satsang, be in their company, or visit the ashram‚Äîthat guru is no longer a guru.‚Äù

At that point, the speaker warns, the guru is no longer leading you from darkness to light. Instead, they have themselves ‚Äúdrowned in darkness.‚Äù The relationship shifts from one of liberation to one of transaction‚Äîor worse, dependency.

---

#### üö© When the Guru Asks You to ‚ÄúBring a Crowd‚Äù

Perhaps one of the most telling signs of a guru‚Äôs fall from grace is when they begin to focus on numbers‚Äîon crowds, influence, and visibility:

> ‚ÄúIf a guru says, ‚ÄòI am arriving at such-and-such place‚Äîbring 50‚Äì100 people, bring your friends, bring that person‚Ä¶‚Äô When the guru‚Äôs intention becomes like a political rally, then that guru and that institution have nothing left to do with spirituality.‚Äù

The shift from inner transformation to outer spectacle is a profound departure from the essence of spiritual teaching. A true guru does not need an audience‚Äîthey serve those who are ready, whether they are one or one thousand.

---

#### üßò A Story of Seeking an Elderly Guru

The speaker shared a revealing anecdote:

> ‚ÄúI knew someone who said, ‚ÄòSwamiji, I was always in search of an elderly guru.‚Äô Why? Because his logic was: ‚ÄòI will take initiation from him, and then he will leave his body. I won‚Äôt have to see him, I won‚Äôt have to meet him, no negative feelings will arise in my mind. I will always hold the highest regard for him.‚Äô‚Äù

There is a certain brutal clarity in this approach. If the guru is no longer physically present, there is no one to correct you, no one to disappoint you, no one to trigger doubt or disillusion. You are left with only the pure teaching‚Äîand your own practice.

While this may sound cynical, it highlights a painful truth: the human tendency to pedestalize spiritual teachers‚Äîand the inevitable fall when they reveal their humanity.

---

#### ‚úã When to Stop‚ÄîEven Midway

One of the most compassionate insights offered was this:

> ‚ÄúWhen your heart does not bear witness, you should stop right there. It is not necessary that you alone should burn in the fire of regret‚Äîthinking, ‚ÄòThe fault is in me, the fault is in me.‚Äô Stop. It‚Äôs okay. No big deal.‚Äù

So often, disciples blame themselves when the relationship with a guru sours. They introspect, repent, and agonize‚Äîconvinced that their own inadequacy is the cause. But the truth is, sometimes the path itself has shifted. Sometimes the guide has lost the way. And it is not only permitted but necessary to pause, step back, and reconsider.

---

### In Summary: Trust Your Inner Witness

The relationship with a guru is meant to be one of the most profound and freeing connections in a seeker‚Äôs life. But it must be rooted in authenticity, humility, and truth‚Äîon both sides.

When the call feels more like a demand,  
When service turns into servitude,  
When silence is replaced by crowd-building,  
When your own heart hesitates‚Äî

**Listen.**

Your inner witness‚Äîthe quiet voice of your own conscience‚Äîis your first and final guru. If it does not affirm the path you are on, do not force yourself forward out of obligation or fear.

As the speaker gently concluded:  
> ‚ÄúStop. It‚Äôs okay. No big deal.‚Äù

The spiritual journey is long, and there are many guides. But the true guru‚Äîthe one who leads you toward light‚Äîwill never ask you to betray your own soul.
